Description: Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Antibiotic nematicide. Antibiotic insecticide. Macrolide insecticide. Block the transmission of electrical activity in invertebrate nerve and muscle cells mostly by enhancing the effects of glutamate at the invertebrate-specific glutamate-gated chloride channel, with minor effects on gamma-aminobutyric acid receptors.
Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Alexidine reduces the production of extracellular polysaccharide, thereby disrupting mature biofilms and reducing adhesion of bacteria on surfaces.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Amikacin irreversibly binds to 16S rRNA and the RNA-binding S12 protein of the 30S subunit of prokaryotic ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis by changing the ribosome's shape so that it cannot read the mRNA codons correctly. Amikacin also interferes with the region that interacts with the wobble base of the tRNA anticodon.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor. Causes a disruption of membrane integrity and ultimately cell death.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. An irreversible inhibitor of the enzyme transpeptidase, which is needed by bacteria to make the cell wall. It inhibits the third and final stage of bacterial cell wall synthesis in binary fission, which ultimately leads to cell lysis. Penicillins acylate the penicillin-sensitive transpeptidase C-terminal domain by opening the lactam ring.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. A echinocandin anti-fungal drug. Active against Aspergillus and Candida species. Anidulafungin inhibits glucan synthase, an enzyme important in the formation of (1â†’3)-Î²-D-glucan, a major fungal cell wall component.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Mitochondrial respiratory-chain inhibitor.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Inositol phosphorylceramide synthase inhibitor. An enzyme inhibitor that inhibits the action of inositol phosphorylceramide synthase.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. A macrolide antibiotic. Inibits prortein biosynthesis. Binds to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome and inhibits translation of mRNA.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Prevent the respiration of fungi due to the disruption of electron transport chain, preventing ATP synthesis. Azoxystrobin binds to the Qo site of Complex III within the mitochondrion.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. A synthetic monocyclic Î²-lactam antibiotic (monobactam), used primarily to treat infections caused by Gram-negative bacteria. It inhibits mucopeptide synthesis in the bacterial cell wall, thereby blocking peptidoglycan crosslinking. EC 2.4.1.129 (peptidoglycan glycosyltransferase) inhibitor. An EC 2.4.1.* (hexosyltransferase) inhibitor that interferes with the action of peptidoglycan glycosyltransferase (EC 2.4.1.129).

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Particularly active against Gram-positive bacteria. Interferes with the dephosphorylation of C55-isoprenyl pyrophosphate, and a related molecule known as bactoprenol pyrophosphate; both of these lipids function as membrane carrier molecules that transport the building-blocks of the peptidoglycan bacterial cell wall outside of the inner membrane.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Benomyl acts by depolymerizing microtubules

Antiprotozoan agent. Any antimicrobial drug which is used to treat or prevent protozoal infections. Inducesf ormation of free radicals and electrophilic metabolites within the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. Induces oxidation occurs mainly in the nucleotide pool.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Bifonazole inhibits fungal ergosterol biosynthesis at two points, via transformation of 24-methylendihydrolanosterol to desmethylsterol, together with inhibition of HMG-CoA.
Antimicrobial agent: A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Succinate dehydrogenase inhibitor.
Phytoalexin. A toxin made by a plant that acts against an organism attacking it.
Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans
A special fluorescent stain that binds strongly to structures containing cellulose and chitin.

Antimicrobial agent: A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. EC 5.99.1.2 (DNA topoisomerase) inhibitor; A topoisomerase inhibitor that inhibits the bacterial enzymes of the DNA topoisomerases, Type I class (EC 5.99.1.2) that catalyze ATP-independent breakage of one of the two strands of DNA, passage of the unbroken strand through the break, and rejoining of the broken strand. These bacterial enzymes reduce the topological stress in the DNA structure by relaxing negatively, but not positively, supercoiled DNA.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Captan is a non-specific thiol reactant that works by inhibiting respiration. Broad spectrum. Non systemic.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. beta lactam class of antibiotic. Inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis. Bind to and inactivates penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs). Inhibit the synthesis of the bacterial cell wall leads to cell death.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Microtubule-destabilising agent. Any substance that interacts with tubulin to inhibit polymerisation of microtubules.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. An irreversible inhibitor of the enzyme transpeptidase, which is needed by bacteria to make the cell wall. It inhibits the third and final stage of bacterial cell wall synthesis in binary fission, which ultimately leads to cell lysis. Penicillins acylate the penicillin-sensitive transpeptidase C-terminal domain by opening the lactam ring.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Mode of action XXXX

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. A semisynthetic cyclic hexapeptide echinocandin antibiotic which exerts its effect by inhibiting the synthesis of 1,3-Î²-D-glucan, an integral component of the fungal cell wall.
Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Inhibits cell wall synthesis via affinity for penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs).

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. A third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic. EC 2.4.1.129 (peptidoglycan glycosyltransferase) inhibitor. An EC 2.4.1.* (hexosyltransferase) inhibitor that interferes with the action of peptidoglycan glycosyltransferase (EC 2.4.1.129)

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Ceftriaxone is a third-generation antibiotic from the cephalosporin family of antibiotics. A Î²-lactam family of antibiotics. Ceftriaxone selectively and irreversibly inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to transpeptidases, also called transamidases, which are penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) that catalyze the cross-linking of the peptidoglycan polymers forming the bacterial cell wall.
Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. A second-generation cephalosporin antibiotic. A class of Î²-lactam antibiotics. Cephalosporins disrupt the synthesis of the peptidoglycan layer forming the bacterial cell wall.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Cefalexin is a beta-lactam antibiotic of the cephalosporin family (1st generation). Inhibits synthesis of the peptidoglycan layer of the bacterial cell wall. Cefalexin irreversibly bind to the active site of a penicillin binding protein (PBP), which is essential for the synthesis of the cell wall.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. A potent broad spectrum antifungal agent. Mode of action not fully elucidated. May selectively inhibits Pkc1.
Antibacterial agent. A broad-spectrum antibiotic that typically stops bacterial growth by stopping the production of proteins. Protein synthesis inhibitor.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Chlorothalonil reduces / deactivates glutathione to gradually remove the pool of reduced glutathione (GSH) . Treated cells accumulate large concentrations of fungicide; reactions involve both low and high molecular-weight thiols, with the formation of glutathione-fungicide derivatives. Toxicity resides ultimately from the inhibition of thiol-dependent enzymes. Broad spectrum. Non-systemic.
Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. A DNA synthesis inhibitor

Antiinfective use to treat liver flukes, specifically fascioliasis and paragonimiasis. A veterinary drug. The molecular mode of action of salicylanilides, including closantel, is not completely elucidated. They all are uncouplers of the oxidative phosphorylation in the cell mitochondria, which disturbs the production of ATP.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Colistin is used to treat Gram-negative infections, partiularly those due to Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Colistin binds to LPSs and phospholipids in the outer cell membrane of Gram-negative bacteria.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. A potent broad spectrum antifungal agent. Exudates, such as hydroxy and amino acids, produced from fungus spores react with the â€œinsolubleâ€ copper fungicides to form soluble toxic copper complexes. This is is supplemented by the copper brought into solution by atmospheric agencies and host plant exudates.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. A potent broad spectrum antifungal agent Exudates, such as hydroxy and amino acids, produced from fungus spores react with the â€œinsolubleâ€ copper fungicides to form soluble toxic copper complexes. This is is supplemented by the copper brought into solution by atmospheric agencies and host plant exudates.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Protein synthesis inhibitor: A compound, usually an anti-bacterial agent or a toxin, which inhibits the synthesis of a protein;

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Cyclosporine A through formation of a complex with cyclophilin inhibits the phosphatase activity of calcineurin, which regulates nuclear translocation and subsequent activation of specific transcription factors.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Inhibits demethylation, a particular step in the synthesis of a component of the fungal cell wall called sterol.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Effective against Gram-positive bacteria. Daptomycin causes the permeabilization and depolarization of the bacterial cell membrane.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Mode of action XXXX

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor. The biosynthesis of ergosterols is critical to the formation of cell walls of fungi.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor. The biosynthesis of ergosterols is critical to the formation of cell walls of fungi.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Used to control black spot and foliar diseases on apples, pears, peaches, nectarines and strawberries. Unknown MOA. Proposed target site cell membrane disruption.

Antimalarial and Antiobacterial agent. A drug used in the treatment of malaria. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Doxycycline inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit. Doxycycline has bacteriostatic activity against a broad range of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.

Antiprotozoan agent. A drug used to treat or prevent infections caused by protozoal organisms belonging to the suborder Trypanosomatida. A substrance that Irreversibly binding to the enzyme ornithine decarboxylase.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Antibiotic insecticide. Macrolide insecticide. Inhibits muscle contraction, causing a continuous flow of chlorine ions in the GABA and H-Glutamate receptor sites.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. EC 1.14.13.70 (sterol 14alpha-demethylase) inhibitor

Antitubercular agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is used in the treatment of tuberculosis. The mechanism of action of ethambutol is not completely known. There is evidence that the drug exerts its bacteriostatic activity by virtue of inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, an enzyme that polymerizes arabinose into arabinan and then arabinogalactan, a mycobacterial cell wall constituent.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. A quorum-sensing molecule. Farnesol inhibits biofilm formation and compromise cell membrane integrity. Farnesol is used by the fungus Candida albicans as a quorum sensing molecule that inhibits filamentation.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. EC 1.14.13.70 (sterol 14alpha-demethylase) inhibitor
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Novel mode of action.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Sterol biosynthesis inhibitor. An inhibitor of ergosterol synthesis.

Antifungal agent used to prevent or treat fungal infections in humans or animals. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor. Any compound that inhibits one or more steps in the pathway leading to the synthesis of ergosterol.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Flucytosine enters the fungal cell via cytosine permease; thus, flucytosine is metabolized to 5-fluorouracil within fungal organisms. The 5-fluorouracil is extensively incorporated into fungal RNA and inhibits synthesis of both DNA and RNA. Flucytosine also appears to be an inhibitor of fungal thymidylate synthase.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Inhibition of transport-associated phosphorylation of glucose as well as preventing glycerol synthesis.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor. The biosynthesis of ergosterols is critical to the formation of cell walls of fungi.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. An aminoglycoside antibiotic. Irreversibly binding the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, negatively impacting protein synthesis.
Antibacterial agent. Gramicidin is active against most Gram-positive bacteria and against select Gram-negative organisms
Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Hygromycin B inhibits polypeptide synthesis. Hygromycin B stabilizes the tRNA-ribosomal acceptor site, thereby inhibiting translation.
Antifungal agent. Antioomycete agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi and oomycetes by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. DNA synthesis inhibitor.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Imipenem inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to and inactivating relevant transpeptidases, known as penicillin binding proteins (PBPs)

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis. Inhibits the enzyme NADH cytochrome c reductase, thereby preventing lipid and membrane synthesis.

Antitubercular agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is used in the treatment of tuberculosis. Inhibits the synthesis of mycobacterial cell wall. Isoniazid is a prodrug and must be activated by a bacterial catalase-peroxidase enzyme in Mycobacterium tuberculosis called KatG. KatG catalyzes the formation of the isonicotinic acyl radical, which spontaneously couples with NADH to form the nicotinoyl-NAD adduct. This complex binds tightly to the enoyl-acyl carrier protein reductase InhA, thereby blocking the natural enoyl-AcpM substrate and the action of fatty acid synthase. This process inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acids, which are required components of the mycobacterial cell wall. A range of radicals are produced by KatG activation of isoniazid, including nitric oxide.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Itraconazole is an antifungal medication used for a number of fungal infections. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor; Hedgehog signaling pathway inhibitor; P450 inhibitor.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor.
Toxin. Poisonous substance produced by a biological organism such as a microbe, animal or plant.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Inhibits protein synthesis. Binds to the 50 S subunits of bacterial ribosomes and preventing peptide bond formation upon transcription. Lincomycin is usually considered bacteriostatic.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Effective against Gram-positive bacteria. Protein synthesis inhibitor. A compound, usually an anti-bacterial agent or a toxin, which inhibits the synthesis of a protein. Linezolid, is also a weak, non-selective, reversible monoamine oxidase inhibitor.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Mancozeb reacts with, and inactivates, the sulfhydryl groups of amino acids and enzymes within fungal cells, resulting in disruption of lipid metabolism, respiration, and production of adenosine triphosphate. Broad spectrum. Non systemic.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. An extended-spectrum penicillin antibiotic that binds specifically to penicillin binding protein 2 (PBP2), and is only considered to be active against Gram-negative bacteria.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. A class of Î²-lactam antibiotics. Meropenem is bactericidal except against Listeria monocytogenes, where it is bacteriostatic. Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. A cyclic hexapeptide echinocandin antibiotic which exerts its effect by inhibiting the synthesis of 1,3-Î²-D-glucan, an integral component of the fungal cell wall.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. . Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor. Inhibits the synthesis of ergosterol, a critical component of fungal cell membranes.

An antiprotozoal drug. Any antimicrobial drug which is used to treat or prevent protozoal infections. Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Protein kinase inhibitor. An EC 2.7.* (P-containing group transferase) inhibitor that interferes with the action of protein kinases. Apoptosis inducer. Any substance that induces the process of apoptosis (programmed cell death) in multi-celled organisms.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Inhibits DNA gyrase, a type II topoisomerase, and topoisomerase IV, enzymes necessary to separate bacterial DNA, thereby inhibiting cell replication

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce.Myriocin is a very potent inhibitor of serine palmitoyltransferase, the first step in sphingosine biosynthesis. EC 2.3.1.50 (serine C-palmitoyltransferase) inhibitor. An EC 2.3.1.* (acyltransferase transferring other than amino-acyl group) inhibitor that interferes with the action of serine palmitoyltransferase (EC 2.3.1.50).

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Precise mechanism of action is unknown, but may involve selectively blocking sterol biosynthesis via inhibition of the squalene 2,3-epoxidase enzyme.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Used to treat Gram-negative bacteria, including the majority of E. coli, Enterobacter, Klebsiella, and Proteus species. DNA synthesis inhibitor. Any substance that inhibits the synthesis of DNA

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. A broad-spectrum highly toxic antibiotic or mixture of antibiotics. Carbohydrate-containing antibiotic.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Generation of superoxide anion and hydrogen peroxide inside the cell leading to oxidative stress.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. A uridine-based nucleoside-peptide antibiotic which inhibits fungal chitin biosynthesis by inhibiting chitin synthase

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Nisin exhibits antimicrobial activity by binding to the pyrophosphate moiety of lipid II, a membrane-bound advanced intermediate involved in the biosynthesis of the cell wall. By doing so, nisin inhibits the transglycosylation step in cell wall biogenesis and sequesters lipid II from its functional location. The nisin-lipid II complex leads to formation of pores in the membrane causing cell death.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Nitrofurantoin is activated by bacterial flavoproteins (nitrofuran reductase) to active reduced reactive intermediates that are thought to modulate and damage ribosomal proteins or other macromolecules, especially DNA, causing inhibition of DNA, RNA, protein, and cell wall synthesis.

Antimicrobial agent. A quinolinemonocarboxylic acid with broad-spectrum antibacterial activity against most gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria. Norfloxacin is bactericidal and its mode of action depends on blocking of bacterial DNA replication by binding itself to an enzyme called DNA gyrase.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans.. EC 5.99.1.3 [DNA topoisomerase (ATP-hydrolysing)] inhibitor. A topoisomerase inhibitor that inhibits DNA topoisomerase (ATP-hydrolysing), EC 5.99.1.3 (also known as topoisomerase II and as DNA gyrase), which catalyses ATP-dependent breakage of both strands of DNA, passage of the unbroken strands through the breaks, and rejoining of the broken strands.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Nystatin is an ionophore. It binds to ergosterol, a major component of the fungal cell membrane. When present in sufficient concentrations, it forms pores in the membrane that lead to K+ leakage, acidification, and death of the fungus.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. ATP synthase inhibitor. A mitochondrial respiratory-chain inhibitor that interferes with the action of ATP synthase. Oligomycin A inhibits ATP synthase by blocking its proton channel (Fo subunit), which is necessary for oxidative phosphorylation of ADP to ATP (energy production).

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Oxacillin, through its Î²-lactam ring, covalently binds to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), which are enzymes involved in the synthesis of the bacterial cell wall. This binding interaction interferes with the transpeptidation reaction and inhibits the synthesis of peptidoglycan, a prominent component of the cell wall. By decreasing the integrity of the bacterial cell wall, it is thought that oxacillin and other penicillins kill actively growing bacteria through cell autolysis
Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Inhibits bacterial DNA-gyrase (topoisomerase II), which is responsible for maintaining the topography of DNA.
Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Protein synthesis inhibitor. Broad-spectrum.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Antiprotozoal drug. An antimicrobial drug which is used to treat or prevent protozoal infections. Anthelminthic drug. A substance intended to kill parasitic worms (helminths). Broad spectrum inhibitor. Paromomycin is a protein synthesis inhibitor, binding to 16S ribosomal RNA.
Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. A Î²-Lactam antibiotic. Inhibits the formation of peptidoglycan cross-links in the bacterial cell wall.

A trypanocidal drug and antifungal agent. A drug used to treat or prevent infections caused by protozoal organisms belonging to the suborder Trypanosomatida. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. NMDA receptor antagonist. Any substance that inhibits the action of N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors. nightmares, and confusion. Due to their psychotomimetic effects, many NMDA receptor antagonists are used as recreational drugs.A chemokine receptor 5 antagonist. An antogonist that blocks chemokine receptor 5 (CCR5). EC 2.3.1.48 (histone acetyltransferase) inhibitor. An EC 2.3.1.* (acyltransferase transferring other than amino-acyl group) inhibitor that interferes with the function of histone acetyltransferase (EC 2.3.1.48). Calmodulin antagonist. An antagonist that interferes with the action of the calcium-binding messenger protein calmodulin. S100 calcium-binding protein B inhibitor. Any inhibitor of S100 calcium-binding protein B.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Fosfomycin inhibits the synthesis of peptidoglycan layer of the bacterial cell wall by blocking the formation of N-acetylmuramic acid. EC 2.5.1.7 (UDP-N-acetylglucosamine 1-carboxyvinyltransferase) inhibitor. An EC 2.5.1.* (non-methyl-alkyl or aryl transferase) inhibitor that interferes with the action of UDP-N-acetylglucosamine 1-carboxyvinyltransferase (EC 2.5.1.7).

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Toxin. Poisonous substance produced by a biological organism such as a microbe.

Antimicrobial agent. . A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Polymyxins interact with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria and are subsequently taken up via the 'self-promoted uptake' pathway. Polymyxins produce a disruptive physicochemical effect, leading to permeability changes in the outer membrane. The affected membrane is thought to develop transient â€˜cracksâ€™ which permit passage of a variety of molecules, including hydrophobic compounds and small proteins, and, more importantly, promote the uptake of the perturbing peptide itself and lead to cell death10 (hence the term â€˜self-promoted uptakeâ€™).

A trypanocidal drug and an antifungal drug. A drug used to treat or prevent infections caused by protozoal organisms belonging to the suborder Trypanosomatida. antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor. A compound that inhibits one or more steps in the pathway leading to the synthesis of ergosterol.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Multiple mechanisms of action.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor. The biosynthesis of ergosterols is critical to the formation of cell walls of fungi.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Pyrimidine antifungal agent. Broad spectrum antifungal. Pyrimethanil inhibits methionine biosynthesis, thus affecting protein formation and subsequent cell division. Inhibits plant cell wall degrading enzymes.

An antifungal and antibacterial agent used to prevent or treat fungal infections and bacterial infections in humans or animals. Rapamycin forms a gain-of-function complex with the 12-kDa FK506-binding protein (FKBP12), and this complex binds and specifically acts as an allosteric inhibitor of mammalian TOR (mTOR, also known as mechanistic TOR) complex 1 (mTORC1).
Phytoalexin: A toxin made by a plant that acts against an organism attacking it.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Antitubercular agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is used in the treatment of tuberculosis. Leprostatic drug. A substance that suppresses Mycobacterium leprae, ameliorates the clinical manifestations of leprosy, and/or reduces the incidence and severity of leprous reactions. EC 2.7.7.6 (RNA polymerase) inhibitor. An EC 2.7.7.* (nucleotidyltransferase) inhibitor that interferes with the action of RNA polymerase (EC 2.7.7.6). Protein synthesis inhibitor. A compound, usually an anti-bacterial agent or a toxin, which inhibits the synthesis of a protein.

Leprostatic drug. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoan. ; Antitubercular agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is used in the treatment of tuberculosis. Protein synthesis inhibitor

A non-systemic insecticide. Interfers with the electron transport chain in mitochondria. Rotenone inhibits the transfer of electrons from iron-sulfur centers in complex I to ubiquinone. This interferes with NADH during the creation of usable cellular energy (ATP).

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Trypanocidal drug. A drug used to treat or prevent infections caused by protozoal organisms belonging to the suborder Trypanosomatida. EC 3.5.1.5 (urease) inhibitor. EC 3.5.1.* (non-peptide linear amide C-N hydrolase) inhibitor that interferes with the activity of urease (EC 3.5.1.5), reducing hydrolysis. EC 1.11.2.2 (myeloperoxidase) inhibitor. An EC 1.11.2.* (oxidoreductase with H2O2 as acceptor, incorporating 1 O atom into product) inhibitor that interferes with the action of myeloperoxidase (EC 1.11.2.2).
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Inhibits protein synthesis in fungi by stabilizing the ribosome/EF2 complex.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Inhibits protein synthesis and elongation by binding to the bacterial 30S ribosomal subunit and interfering with peptidyl tRNA translocation.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Sterol biosynthesis inhibitor; An inhibitor of ergosterol synthesis.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. a protein synthesis inhibitor. Streptomycin binds to the small 16S rRNA of the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, interfering with the binding of formyl-methionyl-tRNA to the 30S subunit.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. QoI inhibitors, which act to inhibit the respiratory chain at the level of Complex III.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Sulbactam is an irreversible inhibitor of Î²-lactamase; it binds to the enzyme and does not allow it to degrade the antibiotic.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. EC 1.14.13.70 (sterol 14alpha-demethylase) inhibitor. Ergosterol biosynthesis inhibitor. The biosynthesis of ergosterols is critical to the formation of cell walls of fungi.
Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Effective against Gram-positive bacterial infections. Inhibit bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Telithromycin is a ketolide, a novel form of macrolide antibiotic. Inhibits protein synthesis. Telithromycin binds to the subunit 50S of the bacterial ribosome, and blocks the progression of the growing polypeptide chain.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Inhibits ergosterol synthesis by inhibiting the fungal squalene monooxygenase (squalene 2,3-epoxidase), an enzyme that is part of the fungal cell wall. synthesis pathway.
Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. A protein synthesis inhibitor.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Compound that contain a benzimidazole moiety as a key feature of their structure. A mainly post-harvest fungicide used to control a wide range of diseases including Aspergillus, Botrytis, Cladosporium and Fusarium.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. A Î²-tubulin inhibitor disturbing cell division.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Inhibit protein synthesis. Targets the 50S bacterial ribosomal subunit and binding to peptidyl transferase, the enzyme responsible for forming peptide bonds between amino acids.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Used in the treatment of Gram-negative bacteria, particularly Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Falls within the larger class of beta-lactam antibiotics,. Prevent cross-linking of peptidoglycan during cell wall synthesis, when the bacteria try to divide, causing cell death.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. A glycylcycline antibiotic, it has activity against a broad range of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, including tetracycline-resistant organisms. A protein synthesis inhibitor. Tigecycline binds to the 30S ribosomal subunit of bacteria and thereby blocking the interaction of aminoacyl-tRNA with the A site of the ribosome. A third generation tetracycline derivative within a class called glycylcyclines

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria, in particular Gram-negative bacteria. Tobramycin works by binding to a site on the bacterial 30S and 50S ribosome, preventing formation of the 70S complex. As a result, mRNA cannot be translated into protein, and cell death ensues.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Inhibits ergosterol biosynthesis.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Histone deacetylase inhibitor. Selectively inhibits the class I and II mammalian histone deacetylase (HDAC) families of enzymes, but not class III HDACs (i.e., sirtuins). Trichostatin A can be used to alter gene expression by interfering with the removal of acetyl groups from histones (histone deacetylases, HDAC) and therefore altering the ability of DNA transcription factors to access the DNA molecules inside chromatin.

Antiinfective used to treat liver flukes, specifically fascioliasis and paragonimiasis, namely Fasciola hepatica (both immature and adult liver flukes), roundworms and ectoparasites. Inhibition of microtubule formation.

Antibacterial agent. Antifungal agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Triclosan acts as a biocide with multiple cytoplasmic and membrane targets. Triclosan targets bacteria primarily by inhibiting fatty acid synthesis. Triclosan binds to bacterial enoyl-acyl carrier protein reductase (ENR) enzyme,[33] which is encoded by the gene FabI. This binding increases the enzyme's affinity for nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This results in the formation of a stable, ternary complex of ENR-NAD+-triclosan, which is unable to participate in fatty acid synthesis. Fatty acids are necessary for building and reproducing cell membranes. Humans do not have an ENR enzyme and thus are not affected by this mode of action.

Antifungal agent and antibacterial agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Inhibits gram-positive bacteria. May act by interfering with the synthesis of proteins. In fungi tridemorph also inhibited sterol biosynthesis.

Antibacterial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of bacteria. Binds to dihydrofolate reductase and inhibits the reduction of dihydrofolic acid (DHF) to tetrahydrofolic acid (THF). THF is an essential precursor in the thymidine synthesis pathway and interference with this pathway inhibits bacterial DNA synthesis.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. EC 2.7.8.15 (UDP-N-acetylglucosamine--dolichyl-phosphate N-acetylglucosaminephosphotransferase) inhibitor. An EC 2.7.8.* (transferases for other substituted phosphate groups) inhibitor that interferes with the action of any UDP-N-acetylglucosaminedolichyl-phosphate N-acetylglucosaminephosphotransferase (EC 2.7.8.15), preventing formation of N-acetylglucosamine lipid intermediates and glycosylation of newly synthesised glycoproteins.

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. A macrolide antibiotic. A bacteriostatic effect. Inhibits protein synthesis through binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome.

Antimicrobial agent. A substance that kills or slows the growth of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi and protozoans. Potassium ionophore: Any ionophore capable of transportation of potassium ions across membranes;

Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Vancomycin inhibits a specific step in the synthesis of the peptidoglycan layer in the Gram-positive bacteria Staphylococcus aureus and Clostridium difficile.
Calcium channel blocker: One of a class of drugs that acts by selective inhibition of calcium influx through cell membranes or on the release and binding of calcium in intracellular pools.
Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. XXX mode of action
Antibacterial agent. A drug used to treat or prevent bacterial infections. Inhibits protein synthesis. Interacts with 50S ribosomal subunits.

Antifungal agent. An antimicrobial agent that destroys fungi by suppressing their ability to grow or reproduce. P450 inhibitor. An enzyme inhibitor that interferes with the activity of cytochrome P450 involved in catalysis of organic substances. Voriconazole is an inhibitor of cytochrome P450 2C9 (CYP2C9) and CYP3A4.
